sub_topic: Calculation of the mass of a substance deposited or dissolved during an electrochemical reaction
message_1: What mass of silver (Ag) will be deposited on a cathode when a current of 5 A is passed through a solution of silver nitrate (AgNO₃) for 10 minutes? The atomic weight of silver is 107.87 g/mol and the Faraday constant is 96,500 C/mol. (Assuming 100% current efficiency and neglecting the mass of the electrodes.)
message_2:
To find the mass of silver deposited on the cathode, we can use the following formula:

mass = (current × time × atomic weight) / (n × Faraday constant)

where:
- mass is the mass of silver deposited (in grams)
- current is the current passed through the solution (in Amperes)
- time is the duration of the current flow (in seconds)
- atomic weight is the atomic weight of silver (in g/mol)
- n is the number of electrons involved in the redox reaction (for silver, n = 1)
- Faraday constant is the charge per mole of electrons (in C/mol)

First, we need to convert the time from minutes to seconds:

10 minutes × 60 seconds/minute = 600 seconds

Now, we can plug in the values into the formula:

mass = (5 A × 600 s × 107.87 g/mol) / (1 × 96,500 C/mol)

mass = (3,000 A·s × 107.87 g/mol) / 96,500 C/mol

mass ≈ 33.42 g

Therefore, approximately 33.42 grams of silver will be deposited on the cathode.
